cnd2:3.1: "Who here in the world is contented": Who is the contented person, the
cnd2:3.2: satisfied person, one whose intentions are complete?
cnd2:4.1: "[Like this]": "Like this," the continuation of the sentences, the connection of
cnd2:4.2: the words, the completion of the sentences, the combination of words, this is
cnd2:4.3: the order of the sentence, which is "like this." "Venerable," this is a synonym
cnd2:4.4: of love, respect, and obedience. "Tissa," the name, title, security of the
cnd2:4.5: Brāhmaṇa, title, word, phrase. "Metteyya," the Brāhmaṇa's surname, name, title,
cnd2:5.1: "For whom there is no wavering": The wavering of love, the wavering of sight,
cnd2:5.2: the wavering of sloth, the wavering of pollution, the wavering of desire; for
cnd2:5.3: whom these waverings do not exist, are not known, have been cut off, calmed
cnd2:5.4: down, stopped, unable to arise, and burned by the fire of wisdom.
cnd2:6.1: "Who has tested both sides": Who, after testing knowledge on both sides, after
cnd2:6.2: understanding, after weighing, after judging, after separating, after
cnd2:7.1: "After consideration, there will be no contamination in the middle": After
cnd2:7.2: consideration, is not contaminated in the middle, no longer contaminated, not
cnd2:7.3: closely contaminated. He has been separated, has left, has been freed, has been
cnd2:7.4: liberated from the bondage, and he has departed, and dwelt without a restrained
cnd2:8.1: "Who do you say is a 'great man'": A great man is the highest man, the most
cnd2:8.2: victorious man, the winner, the first, the top. Who do you say, who are you
cnd2:8.3: telling of, who are you talking about.
cnd2:9.1: "Who has surpassed the tailor here": Who arrived here, conquered the tailor,
cnd2:9.2: thirst for love, has passed, crossed, overcome.
cnd2:10.2: Among the desires, there are Brāhmaṇas
cnd2:10.3: Who are always mindful and detached from desire.
cnd2:10.5: For him there is no wavering.
cnd2:10.7: Among the desires, there are Brāhmaṇas
cnd2:10.8: Who are always mindful and detached from desire.
cnd2:10.10: For him there is no wavering.

cnd2:10.15: For him there is no wavering.

cnd2:10.23: Who are always mindful and detached from desire.
cnd2:10.25: For him there is no wavering.
cnd2:11.1: "There are Brāhmaṇas, among the desires": "Desire," there are two types of
cnd2:11.2: desires: the desire for things and the desire for pollution. What are the
cnd2:11.3: desires for things? Desirable sight, sound, smell, taste, touch; bedding,
cnd2:11.4: clothing, maidservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants, cows,
cnd2:11.5: horses, mules, horses, fields, houses, gold, gold coins, villages and towns,
cnd2:11.6: capitals, countries, territories, treasuries, warehouses; everything that can be
cnd2:11.7: tainted by greed is the desire for things.
cnd2:12.1: In addition, there are past desires, future desires, present desires, internal
cnd2:12.2: desires, external desires, internal and external desires, inferior desires,
cnd2:12.3: medium desires, superior desires; desires in the suffering world, human desires,
cnd2:12.4: heavenly desires, existing desire, created desire, uncreated desire, created
cnd2:12.5: desire by others, possessed desire, unpossessed desire, cherished desire,
cnd2:12.6: non-cherished desires; the desires of all the worlds of desire, the desires of
cnd2:12.7: all the worlds of physicality, all the desires of the world of non-material
cnd2:12.8: worlds, dependence on thirst and desire for love, desiring righteousness, greed
cnd2:12.9: for righteousness, the desire to be intoxicated by righteousness and happiness,
cnd2:12.10: is called the desire for things.
cnd2:13.1: What is the desire for defilement? The desire for desire, the desire for greed,
cnd2:13.2: the desire of desire to greed, the desire of intention, the desire for lust, the
cnd2:13.3: desire for intention, the joy of desire, love obsession, the binding harness of
cnd2:13.4: desire, attachment, the desire for cover.
cnd2:14.2: Wanting to be produced by thought (intention),
cnd2:14.3: I will not think of them,
cnd2:15.1: These are called polluting desires. Craving, thirst, attachment, it is greed,
cnd2:16.1: Brāhma is called separation, abstinence, withdrawal, renunciation, departure,
cnd2:16.2: inaction, no offense, and no transgression from non-rectification, etc. Or, with
cnd2:16.3: no difference, Brāhmaṇa is called the eight branches of the holy path, namely:
cnd2:16.4: right view, right will, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right
cnd2:16.5: diligence, right mindfulness, right concentration. Those who have fully
cnd2:16.6: possessed, entered, walked in, these eight holy paths, he is called a Brāhmaṇa.
cnd2:16.7: For example, he is called a "property person" by property; he is called a person
cnd2:16.8: with wealth; he is called a person with reputation; and he is called a person
cnd2:16.9: with technology. Skilled people; precepts are called "precepts;" one with vigor
cnd2:16.10: is called a "vigorous one;" ones with wisdom are called "wise ones;" in the same
cnd2:16.11: way, anyone who possesses, fully possesses..., these eight noble paths, he is
cnd2:17.1: "Metteyya," the Blessed One calls the Brāhmaṇa by his surname. "The Blessed One"
cnd2:17.2: is synonymous with respect. In addition, the "greed breaker" is the Blessed One;
cnd2:17.3: the "sickness destroyer" is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed conceit"
cnd2:17.4: is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the thorns" is the Blessed One;
cnd2:17.5: "the one who has destroyed the pollutants" is Blessed One; "the one who has
cnd2:17.6: ended" is the Blessed One; "the one who has practiced the body, the precepts,
cnd2:17.7: the mind, and the wisdom" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is close to
cnd2:17.8: the woods, wild forests, and border dwellings (sitting place), where speaking is
cnd2:17.9: lessened, it is quiet, away from the human atmosphere, alone, and suitable for
cnd2:17.10: sitting alone" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is the one who divides
cnd2:17.11: clothes, food, shelter, the needs of patients, and medical necessities"; or "the
cnd2:17.12: Blessed One is the one who has the taste of righteousness, the taste of Dhamma,
cnd2:17.13: the taste of liberation, the increased precepts, the mind, and the wisdom"; or
cnd2:17.14: "the Blessed One is the four types of jhāna, the four immeasurables, the four
cnd2:17.15: formlessness, etc., the one who divides is the Blessed One"; or the Blessed One
cnd2:17.16: is the one who has the eighth liberation, the eight victories, the ninth
cnd2:17.17: dwelling place, etc.; or the Blessed One is the practice of ten thoughts, (ten)
cnd2:17.18: abidings, the one who (observes) the in and out of breath; the one who is purely
cnd2:17.19: divided is the Blessed One; or the Blessed One divides the four mindfulness, the
cnd2:17.20: four righteousness, the four divine bases (iddhipāda), the five faculties, the
cnd2:17.21: five powers, the seven enlightenment factors, and the eight branches of the holy
cnd2:17.22: path; or the Blessed One is ten Tathāgata, four fearlessness, four unobstructed
cnd2:17.23: solutions, six supernatural powers and the six enlightenment methods. "Blessed
cnd2:17.24: One," this name is not given by the mother; not given by the father; not given
cnd2:17.25: by brothers; not given by sisters; not given by friends; not given by relatives;
cnd2:17.26: not given by Samaṇas or Brāhmaṇas; not given by heaven; it is ultimate
cnd2:17.27: liberation; the establishment (of the pseudonym) for the acquisition and
cnd2:17.28: testimony of the Buddha, the Blessed One, under the Bodhi tree, and all
cnd2:17.29: knowledge and wisdom, that is, the Blessed One.
cnd2:18.1: "Always mindful, detached from desire": The desire of "desire for love" is the
cnd2:18.2: thirst for dhammas. For him for whom the desire for love has been cut off and
cnd2:18.3: calmed down, halted, unable to arise, burned away by the fire of wisdom, he is
cnd2:18.4: called the one who is detached from thirst, the one who abandons thirst, the one
cnd2:18.5: who eliminates thirst, the one who releases the thirst, the one who dismisses
cnd2:18.6: the thirst, the one who renounces the thirst, those who are not greedy, those
cnd2:18.7: who abandon greed, who exclude greed, free themselves from greed, renounce
cnd2:18.8: greed, those who do not hunger and thirst, those who have become cool, those who
cnd2:18.9: feel happy, those who regard themselves as Brāhmaṇas. "Always," always,
cnd2:18.10: everything, all the time, eternally, constantly, continuously, uninterrupted,
cnd2:18.11: successively; like waves in water waves arising without pausing; in the morning,
cnd2:18.12: afternoon, first watches of the night, midnight, last night; in the black moon,
cnd2:18.13: bright moon, rainy season, winter, summer; in youth, middle age, and old age.
cnd2:19.1: The "person mindful of" is mindful in four ways: when practicing mindfulness on
cnd2:19.2: the body, when practicing mindfulness on perception, when watching the mind in
cnd2:19.3: the heart, when the practice is in line with the teachings, it is mindful.
cnd2:20.1: And again in four ways: the state of avoiding non-mind, the state of the Dhamma
cnd2:20.2: that should be done to the mind, the state of the Dhamma that is obstructed by
cnd2:20.3: the mind, the state of the mindfulness factor (phase) not being forgotten.
cnd2:21.1: And again in four ways: the state of possessing mindfulness, the state of
cnd2:21.2: abiding in mindfulness, the state of experiencing mindfulness, and the state of
cnd2:22.1: And again in four ways: with the state of being mindful as the object of
cnd2:22.2: mindfulness, the quiet state as the object, the calm state as the object, the
cnd2:22.3: state of silence; the recollection of the Buddha, the recollection of the
cnd2:22.4: Dhamma, the recollection of the Saṅgha, the precepts, the alms, of the mind;
cnd2:22.5: mindfulness of the in and out breath, of death, of the body, of silence; all
cnd2:22.6: mindfulness, free-mindfulness..., the path without a fork, are called
cnd2:22.7: mindfulness. Having been fully possessed, reaching fully, possessing, arriving,
cnd2:22.8: with this thought, he is called mindful.
cnd2:23.1: "Bhikkhu," he who destroyed the state of the seven dhammas is called Bhikkhu;
cnd2:23.2: seeing is destroyed, suspicion is destroyed, prohibition..., greed..., anger...,
cnd2:23.3: delusion..., sloth...; those evil and unwholesome dhammas are destroyed:
cnd2:23.4: shunning pollution (defilement), the others, the fear, the bitter fruit, will no
cnd2:24.5: The one who has been completed,
cnd2:24.6: The one who is extinct, he is a Bhikkhu."
cnd2:25.1: "After considering it, this extinguished bhikkhu": After consideration, it is
cnd2:25.2: called wisdom, understanding, simple selection, investigation, discernment,
cnd2:25.3: recognition, discrimination, close observation, inspection, learned virtuous
cnd2:25.4: wisdom, proficiency, cleverness, study, reflection, review, contemplation,
cnd2:25.5: examination, general comprehensive wisdom, vipassanā, right knowledge, stabbing
cnd2:25.6: rod, wisdom root, wisdom sword, wisdom palace, wisdom brightness, wisdom light,
cnd2:25.7: no delusion, choice of dhamma, right view. "After consideration," after knowing,
cnd2:25.8: after understanding, after measurement, after judgment, after separation, after
cnd2:25.9: clarification: "all activities are impermanent" after consideration...,
cnd2:25.10: "everything is suffering..., "all things are non-self"..., "arising from
cnd2:25.11: ignorance"..., "any collection of dhammas is an extinction of dhammas"....
cnd2:26.1: Or, (seen as) the consideration of impermanence, after knowing..., it is
cnd2:26.2: suffering..., it is disease..., it is tumors..., it is the arrow....
cnd2:26.3: "Extinguished," the state of creating greed is extinguished, of anger, of
cnd2:26.4: ignorance, of resentment, hate, hiding of evil, domineering (arbitrariness,
cnd2:26.5: bossiness, tyranny), jealousy, stinginess, falseness, cunning, stubbornness,
cnd2:26.6: passion, sloth, torpor, discomfort, all pollution, all evil deeds, all troubles,
cnd2:26.7: all irritation, all heat (of torment), all unwholesome contrived things.
cnd2:26.8: "Bhikkhu," the one who has destroyed the state of the seven dhammas is a
cnd2:26.9: Bhikkhu... (omitted); the one who has been completed and the one who has been
cnd2:27.1: "There is no wavering for him": "For him," for the Arahant, for the one who has
cnd2:27.2: exhausted his troubles. "Wavering," the wavering of craving, the wavering of
cnd2:27.3: seeing, ...of sloth, ...of pollution, ...of desire, for him these waverings do
cnd2:27.4: not exist, are not known, are not found, and have been cut off, calmed down,
cnd2:27.5: ceased, unable to arise, burned by the fire of wisdom.
cnd2:28.2: By consideration he is not stuck in the middle,
cnd2:28.3: I say they were a "great man,"
cnd2:28.4: And he surpasses the tailor here.
cnd2:28.7: By consideration he is not stuck in the middle,

cnd2:29.1: "Knowing both sides, after considering it, he will not be contaminated in the
cnd2:29.2: middle": "Side," touch (contact) is one side, touch aggregation is the second
cnd2:29.3: side, touch cessation is in the middle; the past is one side, the future is the
cnd2:29.4: second side, and the present is in the middle; pleasure is on one side,
cnd2:29.5: suffering is the second side, and neither suffering nor pleasure is in the
cnd2:29.6: middle; name is one side, form is the second side, consciousness is in the
cnd2:29.7: middle; the six inner places are one side, and the six outer places are the
cnd2:29.8: second side, and consciousness is in the middle; the body is one side, the body
cnd2:29.9: aggregation is the second side, and the body disappears in the middle. After
cnd2:29.10: consideration, it is called wisdom, which is knowing, understanding
cnd2:30.1: "Adhesion": There are two types of adhesion: the adhesion of craving and the
cnd2:30.2: adhesion of seeing...; this is the adhesion of craving...; this is the adhesion
cnd2:30.3: of seeing. What is craving adhesion? All boundaries, realms, scopes, borders,
cnd2:30.4: are grasped, and are treated as one's own: this is mine, this is mine, so much
cnd2:30.5: is mine, this area is mine; (my) form, sound, smell, taste, touch, things on the
cnd2:30.6: ground, coats, maids and male servants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs,
cnd2:30.7: elephants, cows and horses, mules, fields, homesteads, gold, coins, villages,
cnd2:30.8: towns, capitals, places, treasuries, warehouses, all the land; because they are
cnd2:30.9: craving and regard them as their own, all one-hundred-and-eight types of
cnd2:30.10: craving. [AN.4.199] This is the adhesion of craving.
cnd2:31.1: What is the adhesion of seeing? There are twenty views of the body, ten evil
cnd2:31.2: views, ten side views, all views like this, evil views, jungle (entangled)
cnd2:31.3: views, desert (barren) views, distorted views, shaken views, clinging,
cnd2:31.4: acceptance, holding, clinging to the bound view, the place where the evil way,
cnd2:31.5: the evil nature, the outside way depend, the clasping of the inversion
cnd2:31.6: (vipariyesa), the clinging of the inversion (viparīta), the inversion
cnd2:31.7: (vipallāsa), the grip of evil, the grip of "(seeing) the real in the unreal,"
cnd2:31.8: all come to the reach of the sixty-two evil views; this is the adhesion of
cnd2:32.1: "After he knows on both sides, after consideration, he is not contaminated in
cnd2:32.2: the middle": He is not contaminated after considering, after knowing, after
cnd2:32.3: understanding, after weighing, after judging, after separating, after
cnd2:32.4: clarifying; not tied, detached, released from bondage, he lives with a heart of
cnd2:33.1: "I said they are a 'great man'": This one is the highest person, the most
cnd2:33.2: victorious person, the winner, the first person, the top person. I call them, I
cnd2:33.3: say of them, I explain them, I speak about them.
cnd2:34.1: Venerable Sāriputta said to the Blessed One: "Great Virtue! Known as 'a person,
cnd2:34.2: a great man,' Great Virtue! What makes one a great man?" "Sāriputta! I say that
cnd2:34.3: those who are liberated are 'great people;' I say those who are not free are
cnd2:35.1: Sāriputta! How to be liberated? Sāriputta! Here, the bhikkhu lives in his own
cnd2:35.2: body to observe the body, zeal, righteous knowledge, and mindfulness, and can
cnd2:35.3: moderate the desire and worry about the world. When he lives in the body to
cnd2:35.4: observe the body, the mind is free from defilements, and he is not clinging.
cnd2:35.5: Freedom from all defilements; in feeling...(omitted) in the heart..., living in
cnd2:35.6: the Dhamma and following the Dhamma, zealous, righteous, and mindful, can
cnd2:35.7: moderate the craving and worry about the world. When he lives in the Dhamma and
cnd2:35.8: follows the Dhamma, the mind is free from the defilements, and free from all
cnd2:35.9: defilements it is without clinging. Sāriputta! In this way, the bhikkhu has a
cnd2:35.10: liberated heart. Sāriputta! I say that those who are liberated are 'big men;' I
cnd2:35.11: say those who are not liberated are 'non-big-men.'"
cnd2:36.1: "He surpassed the tailor here": The tailor is called craving, which is greed,
cnd2:36.2: thirst, ...(omitted), and unwholesome roots. For him, this tailor, whose thirst
cnd2:36.3: is cut off, severed, calmed down, ceased, unable to arise, burned by the fire of
cnd2:36.4: wisdom, he has surpassed, conquered the tailor, his desire for love, has passed,
cnd2:36.5: has been crossed, has been overcome.
cnd2:37.1: At the end of these verses... (omitted). "The Blessed One is my teacher and I am
